partintro.para:
We first need to talk about souls and where they emanate from. Klipah is the Hebrew word for shell; a shell or rind of a fruit, for instance. Just as klipah blocks one from getting to the good fruit inside, so too, klipah blocks Godliness from being seen in this world. There are four major kinds of klipah. There are three completely impure and opaque klipot called klipat tameyut that does not allow any Godliness to shine through it. There is a fourth klipah which is a mixture of pure and impure called klipat nogah, which is an illuminating shell.
Tanya, Ch. 1 It is not opaque, but translucent and allows Godliness to shine through it.

Every living thing with blood in its body has an animal soul called a nefesh behemut and a Godly soul called a nefesh Elokit. The nefesh behamut emanates from the klipot. The nefesh Elokit is truly a part of haShem. Everyone can detect their nefesh behemut, but not everyone can detect or is ruled by their nefesh Elokit. All nefeshot behemut emanate from some type of klipah depending on what type of nefesh behemut it has. Unlike the nefesh behemut that emanates from klipah, the nefesh Elokit emanates completely, and is directly a part of, haShem.

While there is only one nefesh Elokit, there are two major kinds of nefashot behemot. Umot haOlam have nefashot behemot that emanate from the three, completely impure, klipot tameyut. Because Umot haOlam emanate from the completely impure klipat tameyut, people that have these animal souls do not detect Godliness on their own and therefore are seemingly completely removed from their nefesh Elokit/Godly soul.

All human beings have a Godly soul called a nefesh Elokit. The nefesh Elokit is completely concealed in the Umot haOlam. It hovers over them and is distant from them as what is called makif rachok.
Ginsburgh, Kabbalah and Meditation for the Nations, page 55-56

Now that we have a little bit of information on the substance of souls, we can now talk about a certain type of soul that the Umot haOlam have. Umot haOlam is translated as "The People of the World". Umot haOlam is the technical term for anyone who is not bnei Yisrael and are connected only to this world and do not have a portion in The World to Come. Umot haOlam are different in contrast to Chasidei Umot haOlam. Chasidei Umot haOlam are not of bnei Yisrael, but are connected to The World to Come. Both Chasidei Umot haOlam and Bnei Yisrael have nefashot behemot/animal souls that emanate from the same place: klipat nogah, which is a mixture of pure and impure and such a nefesh can be elevated; this is where all clean animals emanate from. A nefesh from the klipat tameyut cannot yet be elevated; this is where all unclean animals emanate from and this is the soul type of Umot haOlam.

Every human being takes an oath in utero to be righteous.
Niddah 30b, Iyov The Umot haOlam have forsaken this oath. All human beings have 613 parts of the body.
Tanya, Ari Kaplan Inner Space, Transforming the Inner Self, pg 38, ft 52
Likutei Torah, Eikev 13b; 14a These 613 parts correlate to the 613 mitzvot written in the Torah and each have a respective conduit that connect to haShem. We you fulfill a mitzvah you complete this conduit and Godliness flows into the world.
Tanya, Iggeret haKodesh, 7

Of those 613 parts, 248 are bones that desire to do mitzvot. All men are called to love haShem.
Rambam, Book of Mitzvot, 3rd Principle(p.17 Touger)
The Umot haOlam forsake the desire to love haShem and are motivated only for self-serving motives.

sidebar.para:
R"AMBAM writes: Every human being who's spirit moves them, can obtain understanding, and with his knowledge, set himself different and stand before haShem, to serve and minister to Him and to know haShem, walking straight as Elokim made him, and can remove the yoke of the thoughts of bnei Adam. This human being is sanctified like the Kadosh Kadoshim. haShem is his portion and heritage forever and will provide what is sufficient for him in this world like He provides for priests and Levites. Thus David, peace be upon him, said "haShem is my lot and my portion; You are my cup; you support my lot."
Tehillim 16:5
Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Shemita v'Yovel 13:13
